ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained knowledge in Stoic doctrine and learned to navigate the history of Stoic thought. I refreshed my own reading knowledge of classical Greek. I was introduced to Epictetus and I read Marcus Aurelius with a new appreciation of the influences of Stoicism on his thought.
Facility in working with and interpreting difficult philosophical texts.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The ability for students to tailor the course requirements to their interests and past experience (choosing the Greek or English track) was a strength. The class could be improved by adding secondary readings to the assigned weekly readings or adding a third thinker (perhaps Sextus Empiricus?)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. I would recommend this course to a student interested in philosophy, ancient history, modern thought reception, religion, or ethics.
